page.title: 13Farming: changes since 1930s
page.content: Local farms have become fewer but lar- ger and workforces smaller. One Wysall farm used to have 7 labourers living in and in the 1939-45 war land army girls and prisoners of war worked there. Today the farmer farms 200 acres but employs only one man, who lives in a tied cottage. Mechanisation has reduced the need for men and horses. This farm once had 12 or 14 working horses; now it has none. Milk- ing machines were introduced 50 years ago but cows had to be tied up in stalls; 10 years ago a milking parlour was installed; feed is given according to milk yield, which has risen, and hygiene is better. Cattle may still be fed hay but silage is better food value and can be cropped twice a year. Modern balers make round hay bales, which are unrolled and spread for animal bedding, so saving labour.
